title: Apparently I'm not Sherlock Holmes
body:
I am a janitor in a hospital. It's not a glamorous job, but it's what I do and I try to do it well. My claim to fame would be helping a woman give birth in a power cut. I didn't do much, but worked to keep her calm until a Doctor came and finished the duty right there in the corridor. I felt really good about that and ever since, I've tried to help out when I can.

We have these people who come to the hospital, we call them dopers. They arrive at A&E and appear to be in agony. They are seen by a Doctor and leave minutes later with a prescription for painkillers. Obviously the hospital gets wise to these people and after a few visits, they are refused an appointment. Usually they cause a fuss, and in the worst cases, smash and break objects in their near vicinity.

However, the clever ones leave with no drama and return later in some sort of disguise. Sometimes it's something as simple as a hat and a different T-shirt, complaining of a different ailment. They make sure to see a different receptionist and if they are lucky enough to get assigned a different doctor, they will leave with another fresh script.

The smarter dopers can run this ruse for weeks before they are caught. Though, if I'm around, they don't get away with it. My job is hard work, but doesn't tax the brain, so it's left free to check out these people and tip off the right person.

I know these people are in pain, whether it's mental or physical. I won't let them take advantage of system, though. The doctors and nurses are overworked already as it is, they don't need dopefiends coming in and taking up their valuable time, just for another hit.

There was this one guy though, that I couldn't pin down. His shtick was genius. He would sit in the waiting room, reading a newspaper, or just patiently biding his time. I'd seen him everyday for the last month. If I wasn't mistaken, he'd always been there.

I wondered if he was a health inspector. If he was, it was the perfect way to play it. No-one knew he was ever there. One day he'd wear blue jeans and a white T-Shirt. On others, he'd wear a suit, everyday different. But I don't forget a face. His facial hair changed - clean shaven, goatee, fully grown beard. Even when his black hair was changed to bleach blonde; I knew it was him. The one constant, his long walking stick.

He'd wait and when an emergency patient came in, he'd calmly get up out of his seat and walk over to them, staying far enough away that no-one asked if he was next-of-kin.

The doctors and orderlies would rush to the patient, stretcher them and disappear through the double doors. The man would follow calmly behind.

I knew what he was doing. He was smart. He knew the patients were in pain, that they'd have liquid morphine on tap as soon as they were out of the operating room; genius.

I watched him through the doors as he patiently followed behind the gurney and entered a room. I reported him to the ward nurse, just like I had the dozens of dopers before.

The next day I asked if they found him. They told me that they didn't see someone who matched the description I gave. They checked the CCTV and nothing...

I saw him that day, sitting in his regular seat, and alerted reception. They looked at me all peculiar. I wanted to point, but didn't want to make a scene. Later that day, I was dragged into my manager's office and told, while they appreciate me looking out for the hospital, they would have to let me go.

I asked why, and they said they wanted a janitor, not Sherlock Holmes. I was devastated.

Two weeks ago, my mother phoned me to say she had chest pains. I was at the job centre, waiting for an interview for another role. I rushed to her house to find her unconscious on the floor.

I phoned the emergency services and within fifteen minutes was in the back of an ambulance on the way to my old place of work.

I rushed into A&E, following the gurney that slammed through the double doors. Everything was a blur. My heart thumped from panic as the stretcher raced through and into the OR. I stopped in my tracks as the man, the same man I'd seen dozens of times before, looked over his newspaper and at my mother. He neatly folded his newspaper and stood up.

"Don't let that man anywhere near us," I shouted at reception while pointing to him.

She ignored my plea and the man slowly but surely made his way towards the OR.

I pushed the doors open and ran after the orderlies.

"John, you'll have to wait out here," one said, as my mother was pushed into theatre.

I obeyed them, and slunk into the chair outside the room. I stared down the hallway, a burning hatred rose in my stomach. I played the scenario over in my head, what I was going to say to him as he tried to steal my mother's morphine. But he didn't emerge through the doors.

I was on edge for what seemed like hours. I continued to stare, though only doctors and patients passed through.

"I'm sorry," a doctor said to me, "we've done all we can. She's in a coma, there's very little chance she will survive."

I was lost for words. Carefully, the orderlies rolled her out of the OR and into a ward a few doors down. I followed.

"You can stay here if you like, John," one of them said.

"Thank you," I replied.

Machines were hooked up and I sat in the chair next to her. Doctors conversed, but I didn't listen. All I did was take her hand and cry.

I gripped her fingers tightly and pleaded with her to get better. Her chest rose and fell in rhythm with the machine next to her.

"I love you, mum," I said, leaning over to kiss her hand.

When I sat up, through tears, I saw the man from the waiting room.

"What are you doing here!" I demanded.

He ignored me and approached my mother's drip.

"Don't you dare!" I shouted, as he reached out his hand. It didn't grab the bag, but instead came to rest on her chest. He picked up his walking stick and held it above his head.

"It's her time," he said, "I'm sorry."

The machines blared out in unison a single tonal beep.

Doctors rushed in, apparently oblivious to the man. He patiently turned, putting his walking stick to the floor and hobbled out of the room.

"I'm so sorry, John. She's gone."

When the tears abated, I left. I was numb. I pushed my way back into the reception. A wall of conversation hit me, as another emergency was in progress. I stepped out of the way, as a gurney, similar to my mother's pushed past.

The man was there, in his favourite seat. He folded up his newspaper, slowly got to his feet and patiently followed the orderlies out towards the OR.

xx
author: ecrowe
